messages: edaa0296dd7e3b29b759e3dd39b9a758 (08:52): by default simple events in HTML 5 are cancelable, but does anybody have an idea about what canceli
edaa0296dd7e3b29b759e3dd39b9a758 (08:52): cancelling an event like timeupdate (HTMLMediaElement) might mean?
edaa0296dd7e3b29b759e3dd39b9a758 (08:54): would cancelling a volumechange event mean setting the volume back to the old value?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:00): edaa0296dd7e3b29b759e3dd39b9a758: canceling an event that has no default action has no effect
edaa0296dd7e3b29b759e3dd39b9a758 (09:08): ok, so that they are cancelable is not practically relevant, still I assume that they should be made cancelable to comply with the spec
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:10): the Web in violation of Web Architecture again, film at 11
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:11): edaa0296dd7e3b29b759e3dd39b9a758: yeah. at some point the spec may be made more sensible about what's cancelable and what isn't
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:11): How can the web be in breach with its own arch.? Oh, wait, this is what happens if you try and spec an overall arch.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:12): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I don't think it is a necessary consequence of trying to spec it

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:12): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: It contradicts itself too much I think to be spec'd, then whenever you try and spec anything more you'll just find more contradictions
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:12): the web doesn't have a coherent architecture
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:12): anyone who's tried working on a web browser can see that
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:13): I haven't, but I can see that :P
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:13): it is best to just swallow that and move on, imho :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:13): man can you imagine if the html5 spec was full of paragraphs like:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:13): Many older HTTP/1.0 and HTTP/1.1 applications do not understand the
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:13): Expect header.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:14): "Um, so?"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:14): (given that this spec is nearly 10 years old, these paragraphs are really getting annoying)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:14): There seem to be a few servers that still send HTTP/0.9 responses to any request
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:15): Which is kinda odd
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:15): XHR is bizarre in that case

edaa0296dd7e3b29b759e3dd39b9a758 (09:15): speaking of web legacy, does anybody know where the default 300x150 box for misc elements comes from? was that the size it happened to be in old netscape or something?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:16): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: what servers send 0.9 responses?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:16): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: are those servers full of security holes, too
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:16): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I dunno. Philip` gave a list of pages that did.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:16): wonders who profides security updates for the Netscape Enterprise Server
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:17): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20080606#l-818
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:17): edaa0296dd7e3b29b759e3dd39b9a758: yeah, i think netscape used that for iframes or ilayers or something, and that's where it comes from

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:17): a friend of mine inhereted the admin duties of a site that has been in existence for quite a while, and some of the content had <plaintext> in the file system assuming 0.9 serving
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:17): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Oddly enough using cURL I don't get that
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:17): but the server software had long since been updated
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:18): http://www.guadeloupe-fr.com/ doesn't work at all in cURL
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:19): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: interesting
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:19): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I wonder if these server really date from the 0.9 era
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:19): the rest seem to be Apache/1.3 with mod_layout
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:19): And work in cURL, yet not in the HTTP client in Java Philip` used
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:19): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: or if there's just an incompetently written script copying stuff to stdout that goes straight to a socket
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:20): hasn't encountered mod_layout
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:20): opens up telnet
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:20): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: www.guadeloupe-fr.com doesn't work with telnet for me
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:20): Nor me
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:21): How bizarre.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:21): Works fine in Safari
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:21): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: the drmarin.galeon.com server is not a 0.9 server
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:21): yeah, the rest aren't
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:21): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I sent a request with a bogus Host header, and I didn't get the same content back
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:22): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: so the request dispatcher is virtual host-aware
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:22): it's just the output part that sucks
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:22): and that's HTTP/1.1
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:22): The rest are sucky output
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (09:22): But it shows that support is still needed (yay)
